title: Are there any countries that have two or more leaders, e.g. two or more prime ministers, two or more presidents or two or more monarchs? - Quora

response.answer_text: Yes. The Roman Republic had two Consuls. Each could veto the other's decisions.San Marino today has two Captains-General, modelled on the Roman Consuls. Once powerful, their role today is mostly ceremonial.Northern Ireland has a Chief Minister and a Deputy Chief Minister. Their roles are identical, except that the Chief Minister has a bit more prestige.Andorra has two Co-Princes : the President of France and the Bishop of Urgel. Their role today is mostly ceremonial.Cambodia had two Co-Prime Ministers in the early 1990s. It broke down when one of the co-Prime Ministers, Hun Sen, decided that he disliked sharing power with his fellow co-Prime Minister, Prince Norodom Ranaridh, and got the army to carry out a coup for him. Almost 30 years later, he's still running the show.Cyprus, prior to the upheaval of the 1970s,had a President and Vice President who were practically equal. They could veto each other's decisions.Switzerland has a seven-member Council of State. Its members are all equal. There is a President, who serves for one year, but - apart from prestige - (s)he is just a member of the Council and does not have any powers that his or her fellow-Councillors do not have.

Andorra has two co-princes. The President of France and the local Spanish bishops take the jobs. San Marino elects two Captains-General for six month terms. Both of those countries operate as more or less traditional parliamentary states these days and the two co-heads of state have little power. In Northern Ireland, the First Minister and Deputy First Minister are in many ways co-heads of government. The devolved government cannot function unless there is support from both the Unionist and Nationalist communities, as represented in the Assembly, for appointing a pair that must work together.

Sparta had two kings (termed archagetai, rather than basileis or wanakes), one from the Agiad dynasty, considered senior, and one from the Eurypontid dynasty. For the benefit of movie addicts, Leonidas I was an Agiad.
Andorra. It has two co-princes. The holder of the bishopric of Urgell in Span and the holder of the office of President of France.
